text:
Personally, I wouldn't go near a per word rate. I think this is a dated way to use copywriters on the cheap.

Project-based or day rates only IMO.

text:
If you go the route <@U012GHRAHDK> suggests, please adjust for the uncertainty you face as a contractor, the insurances you need to get, the continuous learning you need to do, your other overhead, and more that you have to pay for yourself that employees don't have to pay or even worry about.

It's a myth that you can earn a lot more as a freelancer / contractor. That only computes if you leave everything out of your rates that really should be included to have a sustainable business and/or compare against what employees are paid and what their employers pay for them.

elements.text: If you go the route

suggests, please adjust for the uncertainty you face as a contractor, the insurances you need to get, the continuous learning you need to do, your other overhead, and more that you have to pay for yourself that employees don't have to pay or even worry about.

It's a myth that you can earn a lot more as a freelancer / contractor. That only computes if you leave everything out of your rates that really should be included to have a sustainable business and/or compare against what employees are paid and what their employers pay for them.

text:
In general, for any freelancer job that requires more than the teensiest level of cognition, don't go below EUR 65,- (EUR 50,- if you're in a COVID-19 related high competition field).

Btw, I tend to convert euros and dollars 1:1 even though the exchange rate is different. Find it easier and you don't get those weird figures. Might adjust by ten either way for higher numbers (when the difference gets bigger).

text: Definitely agree with <@UJJFDTN8G> about payment terms and more info. I usually go into "re-writes" with a very similar mindset and project terms I use for a net new piece, especially if the pieces are more than a couple of years old. Often refreshes and re-writes tend to take a little more work than net new ones, in my experience. But if you gain more info, and the guides are newer, you can maybe scale back on your proposal a little bit.

text:
For those of you who are part of an in-house content team, do you have roles that are strictly focused on writing/content creation, or do most team members have some level of other responsibilities for research, driving parts of your content strategy, collaborating with other teams etc? 

We have a content specialist role which is more the latter (about 75% writing and 25% other) and anyone who is solely writing/executing (no other responsibilities) would usually be a freelancer. I’m curious how others set up their internal teams and what you’ve found works well.

elements.text:

We have a content specialist role which is more the latter (about 75% writing and 25% other) and anyone who is solely writing/executing (no other responsibilities) would usually be a freelancer. I’m curious how others set up their internal teams and what you’ve found works well.

text: We have 4 content marketers when fully staffed, and one copywriter. (A distinction about which I have THOUGHTS, but perhaps another day…) We definitely lean toward writers vs strategists, but I don’t know where the rest of our time goes. We’ve ramped up our work with freelancers for most of the quick output.

text: Hey Kate. While I mainly do project-based pricing, I use $65/hr to estimate those projects, plus a 5-10% buffer (I historically underestimate). A friend of mine with more experience does $125. I know specialized copywriters (especially conversion) charge even higher, depending on the company size, niche, and name they've built for themselves.

A friend of mine with more experience does $125. I know specialized copywriters (especially conversion) charge even higher, depending on the company size, niche, and name they've built for themselves.

text:
Thanks for the input <@U012UL77GUT> .

The guides aren't exactly old but they weren't written with SEO in mind (which is the major thing the client wants help with).

You're also so right about re-writes taking longer. The more I look through the guide, the more I see just how much work will have to go into it. (And not just optimising it for search engines).

I'm most definitely going with a flat rate or day rate on this one so I can set my fee at an amount that makes it worth the effort.

text:
Hahaha <@U016AG4A2G2> right there with you, that sounds like a conversation for a few virtual beers. 

Our team is small, me (manager of 3, focused on strategy and campaigns) with one content strategist (about 40% content creation or oversight, 40% strategic projects and 20% non content leadership role in employee programs) and a content specialist who I mentioned above. 

I’m not planning to hire anytime soon but our team has always used this “specialist” approach where someone’s a jack of all trades but mostly a writer.  I’ve been debating whether it makes sense to really focus someone’s work on execution rather than participating in all the wraparound support and projects and move more of those to the strategist. Depends a lot on individual growth interests but I’m just curious to hear how others handle it!

text:
I've played both parts- a freelancer on teams where I'm handed a solid brief (written up and researched by a content strategist and SEO) and left to write and approve edits by their editor, as well as managed writers as a content lead.
As a freelancer, I'm happy to be as involved as the team needs me. And as a content lead, we hire writers with knowledge in the space and allow them to write and research with more freedom. But I'm a content lead for a startup, so our process isn't as evolved as I would like it to be.

elements.text:

text:
t-shaped, people, c'mon now. Everybody has their specialty / specialties but knows enough of other people's jobs to get things done and finished when things get tight, you're in a crunch, or just because it's fun to flex your muscles.

And I totally agree with "Depends a lot on individual growth interests", <@URB31QKM4>

I really don't understand why anyone would want to pigeonhole individuals who are capable of and interested in much more.

I'll get off my high :horse: now.

text:
I'm often sketching my campaign ideas on paper and end up forgetting which notebook or pad I drew/wrote it down on. Does anyone use an electronic notebook they can recommend? I'm trying to stay away from a multipurpose iPad, I'd like a notepad that's specifically for taking notes and saving that to the cloud

I had my eye on the reMarkable e-ink writer but they're not shipping until November and I'm in need of a solution now :(

text: This message was deleted.

Great topic, <@URB31QKM4>

I’m also a Manager of three, but I oversee the production of another writer as well. I’m the strategist - more focused on assigning topics, creating briefs, and looking at the results. I also jump in and write when we’re at capacity - which means I write daily. 

We have one writer really focused on updating old content for SEO purposes, creating new TOF SEO content, and acting as our primary “final set of eyes.” More “long-form content.” She’s our newest hire and has been a great add. She came from a journalism background. 

We also have a writer that is primarily “short-form” content. He works on email copy, product copy, and sales enablement copy. 

Finally I have a Visual Storyteller and a Marketing Coordinator on my team. The Visual Storyteller is our videographer and he has always remained on the content team. I’ve worked with him for three years and while I can’t give him a ton of technical feedback - we work extremely well together creating videos to rank in search, and telling a story. 

The Marketing Coordinator handles social media and webinars. She’s moving more into a project coordinator position. 

I’m considering bringing on freelance writers in Q4 as my writers are extremely busy. Hoping to find one that understands our product and target audience.

We have one writer really focused on updating old content for SEO purposes, creating new TOF SEO content, and acting as our primary “final set of eyes.” More “long-form content.” She’s our newest hire and has been a great add. She came from a journalism background. 

We also have a writer that is primarily “short-form” content. He works on email copy, product copy, and sales enablement copy. 

Finally I have a Visual Storyteller and a Marketing Coordinator on my team. The Visual Storyteller is our videographer and he has always remained on the content team. I’ve worked with him for three years and while I can’t give him a ton of technical feedback - we work extremely well together creating videos to rank in search, and telling a story. 

The Marketing Coordinator handles social media and webinars. She’s moving more into a project coordinator position. 

I’m considering bringing on freelance writers in Q4 as my writers are extremely busy. Hoping to find one that understands our product and target audience.

text:
I tried a Rocketbook but I just couldn't get into it/make it work.
It's no different than writing in a paper notebook, taking a picture of it with your phone, and uploading it to your preferred online storage. Then, it's not that easy to organize and reference.
I recently bought an iPad Mini 5 and an Apple Pencil. I downloaded both GoodNotes and Notability to test it out. Love them both. haha.
You can customize your pencil size and figure out what works best to get you as close as possible to using a normal notebook. I'm loving it.
I have not tried the reMarkable but I'm sure it's neat!

elements.text:

I recently bought an iPad Mini 5 and an Apple Pencil. I downloaded both GoodNotes and Notability to test it out. Love them both. haha.
You can customize your pencil size and figure out what works best to get you as close as possible to using a normal notebook. I'm loving it.
I have not tried the reMarkable but I'm sure it's neat!

text:
Hey everyone! I’m looking to do a pretty massive content prune and reorganization of our blog. We consistently get 100k+ monthly unique visitors, but they don’t stick around much. I’ve been reading up on using hub pages with the hope that better navigation and structure will push people to stick around and move through our funnel. Two questions:
1. Does anyone have experience reorganizing a blog with hundreds of articles into something more focused like this? Any resources or tips you can share?
2. Does URL structure for hub pages/categories really matter? (i.e. <http://site.com/hub/blog-post-1|site.com/hub/blog-post-1>) This seems to be “best practices” in a lot of articles but I’ve rarely seen it in practice.

elements.text: Hey everyone! I’m looking to do a pretty massive content prune and reorganization of our blog. We consistently get 100k+ monthly unique visitors, but they don’t stick around much. I’ve been reading up on using hub pages with the hope that better navigation and structure will push people to stick around and move through our funnel. Two questions:
Does anyone have experience reorganizing a blog with hundreds of articles into something more focused like this? Any resources or tips you can share?
Does URL structure for hub pages/categories really matter? (i.e.
site.com/hub/blog-post-1
) This seems to be “best practices” in a lot of articles but I’ve rarely seen it in practice.

text:
That tweet thread by Tom Hirst is also available as an article now: <https://www.tomhirst.com/pricing-freelance-projects/>

and a book expanding on it will become available on July 30th. You can pre-order it on Gumroad: <https://gumroad.com/l/pcUlz>

attachments.title: Pricing Freelance Projects
attachments.text: Everything I've learned about pricing freelance projects in 11 years of doing it. The article about the Twitter thread.

attachments.title: Pricing Freelance Projects
attachments.text: Pricing Freelance Projects is a book I've always wanted to write. On 30th July 2020, I'll release it. I posted a Twitter thread summarising my experience, learning and knowledge of pricing real-world freelancing services. And it took off. At the time of writing, the thread has received 36,500 likes and 10,900 retweets. My message has been seen 2.8 Million times by people. Its content has been re-worked and re-posted around the world. I’ve had countless messages of thanks for sharing my condensed version of 11 years in pricing freelance work. I’d already thought about writing a book on pricing for freelancers, but this response was the catalyst. Along with the wide-reaching positivity, my approach received questions too. More than I could keep up with in real-time. Many freelancers have asked for a level of expansion on my thinking and methods that would be better suited to a longer-form medium than Twitter. This was the moment that I decided I had to write this book. The good news is, I’ve got a lot more to say. Whether you’re thinking about going freelance, you’re a new freelancer or you’re a seasoned pro with years of experience behind you: Pricing is complex. Pricing is personal. . Pricing has layers. Pricing is fluid. Pricing is an art. I’ve made it my mission to understand pricing deeply to get paid what I’m worth throughout my freelancing career. And this mantra makes me a great living from freelancing year on year. Pricing Freelance Projects is not "just another value-based pricing system". This book shows you how to understand, raise and retain your value on a per-project basis. This book teaches you how to apply value realistically to know what to charge and get paid what you're worth. This book expands heavily on the Twitter thread that freelancers loved and provides answers to their questions. This book contains everything that I know about pricing freelance work. And there’s tons of value in it for you. The Plan. I've had Pricing Freelance Projects drafted for a while and the plan has always been to write it. The attention my writing on pricing has received recently has accelerated this process. Writing has already started. The book will be released for download on 30th July 2020. I'll provide updates between then and now as creation unfolds. Follow me as I write, edit and launch Pricing Freelance Projects on Twitter! <https://twitter.com/tom_hirst>. Pre-Order Now. By clicking the "I want this!" button, you're locking in your copy of Pricing Freelance Projects for the special pre-order price of $19. After the book is launched on 30th July 2020, the price to purchase Pricing Freelance Projects will be higher. Praise So Far. Here's just some of the praise I've received so far: Free Updates For Life. Purchase of Pricing Freelance Projects comes with free updates for life. Any time I make an edit or addition to the book, you'll get it at no further cost. Money-Back Guarantee. I only want your money if Pricing Freelance Projects provides you with value. If within 30-days of your purchase (within 30-days of the launch date for pre-orders) the book isn't what you expected, send an email to <mailto:hello@tomhirst.com|hello@tomhirst.com>, let me know why and I'll refund you. FAQ. Who is this book for exactly? Pricing Freelance Projects is for freelancers, people thinking about going freelance, consultants, small-agencies, entrepreneurs and solopreneurs. It's for designers, developers, writers, SEOs and more. It's for anyone who sells services or products to clients. While my vantage point of pricing is from a freelancing perspective, I've had feedback from people in each of these fields that my approach adds value. Does buying this book guarantee that I will make more money? Absolutely not. Pricing Freelance Projects is the story of my experiences and I don't guarantee that you will see the same level of success. Applying this knowledge requires individual effort and is dependant on your specific circumstances and other external factors. Got a specific question? Send an email to <mailto:hello@tomhirst.com|hello@tomhirst.com> with the details, I'll be happy to help. What Now? Now's your chance to guarantee your copy of Pricing Freelance Projects for a cheaper price. Now's your chance to get over a decade's worth of knowledge on pricing freelance projects for a fraction of the cost that the lessons learned could earn you. Click the "I want this!" button now to learn how to use value realistically to know what to charge and get paid what you're worth. Thanks for reading!

text: Re: #1 - no. That makes my stomach hurt just to think about it. BUT! Do you already have a full inventory of what you have, like in a spreadsheet or something? If not, I suggest using something like Screaming Frog. I’ve also done gap analyses by creating topic clusters - which would then help you gain clarity on what needs to go where. Hope this is somewhat helpful; may be stuff you already know though.

elements.text: Re: #1 - no. That makes my stomach hurt just to think about it. BUT! Do you already have a full inventory of what you have, like in a spreadsheet or something? If not, I suggest using something like Screaming Frog. I’ve also done gap analyses by creating topic clusters - which would then help you gain clarity on what needs to go where. Hope this is somewhat helpful; may be stuff you already know though.

text: I look at rewrites as new projects as well! From the outside looking in I can see how a client may think it’s easier to start with something, but sometimes it takes extra effort to fit around the content (rather than do it all from you).

elements.text: I look at rewrites as new projects as well! From the outside looking in I can see how a client may think it’s easier to start with something, but sometimes it takes extra effort to fit around the content (rather than do it all from you).

text: Definitely! I did a content audit using Screaming Frog and Ahrefs to identify posts that can just be deleted (So I have less to deal with!) But it got overwhelming pretty quickly. Any resources on doing gap analysis?

text:
For gap analysis, would highly recommend ahrefs (also helps with seeing what content gaps exist for your competitors).

I’m actually working on a reorganization (and production) of pages under our domain and would recommend this <https://foundationinc.co/lab/canva-seo|case study> about Canva as a way to think about organizing content.

text:
I would prune first and see what you're left with.

Then investigate the technical ramifications of doing a whole bunch of redirects at once.

You may be best served by focusing on interlinking and forming ad hoc topic clusters off of what you already have & making sure those are well connected, and filling in the gaps w/ new content

MarketMuse is great at helping to form topic clusters

text:
I'm currently undoing the Pinterest presence I inherited, as it's just not a great B2B channel.

I found this post from CoSchedule useful — it has some data about the use of Pinterest. Nothing super surprising, but the main takeaway is that Pinterest is mostly used by people outside of working hours to browse for home, food, and lifestyle consumer goods. (The post says the best time to post is 8-11pm on Sat, which is quite revealing).

text: <https://coschedule.com/blog/how-to-use-pinterest-for-business/>

1. I did a massive pruning project and just made use of Google Sheets. But I've seen people from this channel vouch for AirTable, because there are some features that can help you better map out which posts will target which keywords. Pruning definitely helps! Definitely use Ahrefs though to make sure you're not not deleting any blogs with tons of backlinks.
2. I don't have data to prove this, but I've read enough smart people say that URL structure matters to believe them. I always try to use a tiered URL structure like this, when possible. That said, it's okay to take a staged approach here. Prune first, restructure second.

text: How do you fine folks feel about a company asking its employees to share its content from their personal LinkedIn profiles (voluntarily, but politely encouraged)? Have any of you done this with some success?

elements.text: How do you fine folks feel about a company asking its employees to share its content from their personal LinkedIn profiles (voluntarily, but politely encouraged)? Have any of you done this with some success?

text: We had a formal program running for a few years to do this. Mediocre results from what I could see. They tried different platforms, incentives, etc... but the friction was too high + content wasn't relevant to most employees.

elements.text: We had a formal program running for a few years to do this. Mediocre results from what I could see. They tried different platforms, incentives, etc... but the friction was too high + content wasn't relevant to most employees.

text: If I were to take it on, I'd identify a smaller group of folks who are interested in really stepping up their social activity and working with them as a sort of virtual advocacy team.

elements.text: If I were to take it on, I'd identify a smaller group of folks who are interested in really stepping up their social activity and working with them as a sort of virtual advocacy team.

text: Thanks Andy! That's my gut feeling—to identify the internal stakeholders that will have more of a vested interest in sharing content (leadership, sales) rather than creating some blanket sharing policy.

elements.text: Thanks Andy! That's my gut feeling—to identify the internal stakeholders that will have more of a vested interest in sharing content (leadership, sales) rather than creating some blanket sharing policy.

text:
Heh, going through this right now. Pulled the data from Google Analytics and prioritized based on page value + traffic.

We're auditing everything (~500 posts) to identify intent, topic focus, and other data that Ahrefs/Screaming Frog would miss. Doing it in Google Sheets. Working around the backlinks by clustering related posts, merging topics with same intent, and 301'ing dropped URLs.

We use a flat URL structure (no category in hierarchy) and sort based on tags, so the same post can surface in different collections.

As long as the navigation path is clear and crawlable, the URL structure shouldn't matter as much, IMO.

elements.text:
Heh, going through this right now. Pulled the data from Google Analytics and prioritized based on page value + traffic.

We're auditing everything (~500 posts) to identify intent, topic focus, and other data that Ahrefs/Screaming Frog would miss. Doing it in Google Sheets. Working around the backlinks by clustering related posts, merging topics with same intent, and 301'ing dropped URLs.

We use a flat URL structure (no category in hierarchy) and sort based on tags, so the same post can surface in different collections.

As long as the navigation path is clear and crawlable, the URL structure shouldn't matter as much, IMO.

text:
Hi <@UUH2ESL66> - I’ve seen it done with a great deal of success and I have also seen it done with mediocre results, a lot of it depends on how well the program is managed and the type of content being put into the program for employees and stakeholders to share. I 100% agree with <@UJ99RGF7T>, start with a small group of employees and refine what works and what doesn’t before scaling up. It can be really powerful if managed correctly.

Full disclosure, I work with GaggleAMP and employee advocacy is our entire business model. If you are ever curious if its something manageable for your team or your employees, we run a platform neutral <https://www.gaggleamp.com/attendamplify|employee advocacy training> designed heavily around how to set up an employee advocacy program to be mutually beneficial for both the employees and company.

text:
Hey stranger <@ULJBEFSJJ> :wink:

I'm factoring Pinterest into my strat for 2021+. I've seen blogger groups (lifestyle, travel, home, entrepreneurs) do really well with CTR.

My theory is that certain reference content can pick up some momentum if paired with a strong graphic (lists, how-tos, etc).

For Wild Apricot, I could see you folks doing well with topics around fundraising, charity, etc. "Fundraising ideas for X" could go a long way.

<https://www.pinterest.ca/search/pins/?q=fundraising> ideas

attachments.title: Pinterest
attachments.text: Discover recipes, home ideas, style inspiration and other ideas to try.

text:
Our old content team was blown up at the start of the year. :cry:

I'm in a middle management/strategy role now, straddling content marketing + social media + customer community. (Too many hats.)

My directs do a mix of editing and admin for different channels. Actual content creation is mostly outsourced to internal and external contributors (writers/editors/presenters).

Dream setup: One manager for each area (blog, social, community) and a small team of creators who can execute on each. Mostly writing and editing with some templated creative.

text:
+1 to <@UJ99RGF7T>’s comments. Working at a martech company, for example, it’s tough to get developers to share content created for marketers. It’s not their network. It’s not their brand. So I really focus on our execs and the “customer” team - marketing, sales, CS - who actually have connections to potential customers.

My husband’s company recently started an internal “influencer” program where the comms team is kind of identifying employees who have an interest in sharing and a decent habit about doing it already, and working with them directly on a steady stream of stuff to share.

elements.text: +1 to
